Zoo and Wild Animal Medicine (Sixth Edition)Links to an external site., Current Therapy, 2008, Pages 375-385 1.3 Worldwide size of livestock industries Dr Stuart Barber srbarber@unimelb.edu.au VETS30030 / VETS90123 Worldwide livestock populations Overall size of international animal population determines total available output from them (whatever any output may be) Each country likely to have different outputs, even from same animal as found in another country Can be challenging to get current, accurate information on domesticated livestock around the world Worldwide sheep flock • Over 1 billion animals • Challenging to get accurate counts given birth rate (often multiple lambs), potentially multiple births per year and also sales • Density in a country can vary from region to region, not evenly distributed http://cdn3.chartsbin.com/chartimages/l_42239_9cd955684ffce310fdfbff06043c6419 https://www.fao.org/typo3temp/pics/7e01d8661d.jpg Worldwide goat herd • About 750,000 goats (smaller than sheep) • Often grown in similar areas Worldwide cattle (beef and dairy) herd • According to https://www.statista.com/statistics/263979 /global-cattle-population-since-1990/ approximately 1 billion cattle • Buffalo also farmed around the world (approximately 200 million buffalo around the world) https://www.fao.org/typo3temp/pics/20734530c8.jpg Deer, alpaca and camel herds • Significant wild deer populations • In the 2000s about 4 million deer farmed, largest populations in NZ (red deer), then USSR next biggest • Approximately 3.5-4 million alpaca, mostly South America (Peru) • Global camel population 25-30 million head in 2013
